G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 19A..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds the minimum jurisdictional amount for civil actions in the District Court Department, exclusive of interest and costs, but does not exceed the maximum jurisdictional amount of the District Court. See G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: All of the acts and omissions giving rise to this action occurred in Newton, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, within the territorial jurisdiction of the Newton Division of the District Court Department. Venue is therefore proper in this Court. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2; G.L. c. 218, § 2.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 2.proposition: All of the acts and omissions giving rise to this action occurred in Newton, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, within the territorial jurisdiction of the Newton Division of the District Court Department. Venue is therefore proper in this Court. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2; G.L. c. 218, § 2.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries and damages were caused solely by the negligence, carelessness, and/or reckless disregard of Defendant, without any contributory negligence on Plaintiff’s part. In any event, any negligence on Plaintiff’s part was less than any negligence of Defendant and does not bar her recovery. See G.L. c. 231, § 85.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care in his or her actions so as to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others. See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146–47 (2006); *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696–97 (2000).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.support_reasoning: The court expressly states a general principle of Massachusetts tort law that "every actor" has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, with foreseeability as the key limitation. That is substantively the same as the proposition that every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care in their actions so as to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others. The opinion thus directly supports the cited general duty rule under Massachusetts law.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.relevant_excerpt: "We have recognized that '[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.' See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor." *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146–47 (2006).

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care in his or her actions so as to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others. See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146–47 (2006); *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696–97 (2000).
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.support_reasoning: The Glidden opinion, at the cited pages, analyzes negligence elements and focuses on the plaintiffs’ failure to prove causation. It does not articulate any general Massachusetts rule that "every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care in his or her actions so as to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others." The court even expressly declines to decide whether the defendant owed a duty of care, resolving the case solely on lack of causation, so it does not provide authority for the broad duty proposition.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss… Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them…”

*Jupin*, 447 Mass. at 147.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and/or person in control of the Dog, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, control, and supervision of the Dog so as to prevent the Dog from creating an unreasonable risk of harm to persons lawfully present in the Park, including Plaintiff. See *Jupin*, 447 Mass. at 147; *Maillet v. Mininno*, 266 Mass. 86, 89 (1929).
*Jupin*, 447 Mass. at 147.support_reasoning: Jupin recognizes a general duty of reasonable care and then, on specific facts, holds that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to a violent, mentally unstable person owes a duty to foreseeably endangered persons such as a police officer. It does not address dogs, animal ownership, or a generalized duty of owners/keepers of animals to protect persons lawfully present in a park. Thus, while it is about duty and foreseeability, it does not provide authority for the specific dog-related duty described in the proposition.
*Jupin*, 447 Mass. at 147.relevant_excerpt: “In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. This duty is owed to, inter alia, a law enforcement officer shot by the person granted unsupervised access, because the officer is a foreseeable victim of the alleged improper firearm storage.” (447 Mass. at 143)

*Maillet v. Mininno*, 266 Mass. 86, 89 (.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and/or person in control of the Dog, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, control, and supervision of the Dog so as to prevent the Dog from creating an unreasonable risk of harm to persons lawfully present in the Park, including Plaintiff. See *Jupin*, 447 Mass. at 147; *Maillet v. Mininno*, 266 Mass. 86, 89 (1929).
*Maillet v. Mininno*, 266 Mass. 86, 89 (.support_reasoning: Maillet v. Mininno is a statutory dog-bite case under G.L. c. 140, § 155, dealing with who may be sued as an “owner or keeper” and whether they can be held jointly liable under the statute. It does not address any common-law duty of reasonable care in the ownership, control, or supervision of a dog, nor does it discuss duties owed to persons lawfully present in a park or elsewhere. Thus it does not support the negligence-based duty proposition for which it is cited.
*Maillet v. Mininno*, 266 Mass. 86, 89 (.relevant_excerpt: G. L. c. 140, § 155, provides: “The owner or keeper of a dog shall be liable in tort to a person injured by it in double the amount of damages sustained by him.” … It was decided in Galvin v. Parker, 154 Mass. 346, that the owner and the keeper of a dog are not liable jointly and severally as tortfeasors under that statute; that an election must be made to sue either the owner or the keeper; and that, if a judgment were obtained against one, no suit against the other could be maintained….

*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.raw_text: *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 359 (1990)
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.proposition: The existence of such laws and posted signs at the Park informed and heightened the standard of reasonable care owed by Defendant. See *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 359 (1990) (violation of statute or regulation is evidence of negligence); *G. L. c. 140*, including §§ 155–174F (regulating dogs).
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that violation of a statute or regulation is evidence of negligence, and cites Bennett for that point. In Bennett, the SJC expressly reiterates the Massachusetts rule that statutory violation is not negligence per se but is instead only ‘some evidence’ of negligence. That directly supports the portion of the proposition that relies on Bennett to show that statutory or regulatory violations can be used as evidence of negligence (though not to heighten the legal standard of care beyond ordinary reasonableness).
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se… Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent.” 408 Mass. at 358-59.

G. L. c. 140, including \u00a7\u00a7 155.proposition: The existence of such laws and posted signs at the Park informed and heightened the standard of reasonable care owed by Defendant. See *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 359 (1990) (violation of statute or regulation is evidence of negligence); *G. L. c. 140*, including §§ 155–174F (regulating dogs).

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: Defendant also owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating situations in which a large, unleashed dog could charge at or threaten park users, thereby causing them reasonably to take evasive action that could result in physical injury. See *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996) (duty extends to foreseeable risk of harm); *Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 731–32 (2000).
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The quoted passage from Poskus is a concurrence focused on causation and the limits of foreseeability, explicitly agreeing that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm. It does not discuss duties related to dogs, evasive action, or a broader duty to avoid creating situations leading to such evasive injuries; rather, it indicates that the risk at issue was not foreseeable. While Poskus touches on foreseeability, it does not affirm the specific duty proposition claimed here.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: I concur in the view that "[t]he facts would not warrant a jurys finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardos negligence." Ante at 640-641.

*Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u2.proposition: Defendant also owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid creating situations in which a large, unleashed dog could charge at or threaten park users, thereby causing them reasonably to take evasive action that could result in physical injury. See *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996) (duty extends to foreseeable risk of harm); *Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 731–32 (2000).
*Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u2.support_reasoning: Luoni v. Berube rejects, rather than recognizes, a duty on social hosts/landowners to control third-party hazardous conduct they did not create, provide, or control. The court expressly states that there is no duty where the defendants “did not provide the harmful item, did not control its use, and did not create the situation that caused the danger,” and it declines to create a new policy-based duty to “police their property” for such risks. That reasoning cuts against imposing a duty to prevent situations where a dog could charge or threaten park users, so the case does not support the cited proposition.
*Luoni v. Berube*, 431 Mass. 729, 731\u2.relevant_excerpt: “[T]he common bond between the decisions involving social host liability for alcohol-related injuries, and the circumstances here, is the fact that the defendants did not provide the harmful item, did not control its use, and did not create the situation that caused the danger… The defendants did not furnish the fireworks or give permission for the display on their property… Their status as social hosts carried with it neither the means, nor the legal obligation, to supervise or prevent the discharge of the fireworks by others.”

*Glidden*, 430 Mass. at 696\u201397.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below that of a reasonably prudent dog owner under like circumstances and constituted negligence under Massachusetts law. See *Glidden*, 430 Mass. at 696–97; *Andrade v. Baptiste*, 411 Mass. 560, 565–66 (1992) (foreseeability and reasonableness standard).

*Andrade v. Baptiste*, 411 Mass. 560, 56.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below that of a reasonably prudent dog owner under like circumstances and constituted negligence under Massachusetts law. See *Glidden*, 430 Mass. at 696–97; *Andrade v. Baptiste*, 411 Mass. 560, 565–66 (1992) (foreseeability and reasonableness standard).
*Andrade v. Baptiste*, 411 Mass. 560, 56.support_reasoning: Andrade v. Baptiste does not involve dogs, dog owners, or the standard of care for dog ownership. It addresses whether a homeowner/wife owed a duty to control her adult husband’s use and storage of his own firearm, and the court ultimately holds that no such duty exists on these facts. While the opinion discusses duty, foreseeability, and reasonableness generally, it does so to reject liability, not to establish a negligence standard for dog owners; using it as authority for that specific dog-owner proposition is therefore inaccurate.
*Andrade v. Baptiste*, 411 Mass. 560, 56.relevant_excerpt: “Whether there is a duty to be careful is a question of law. … In our view, sound social policy would clearly not be advanced by a rule which would hold the defendant liable in these circumstances.”

*Jupin*, 447 Mass. at 147\u201348.proposition: It was foreseeable to Defendant that a person confronted with a large, barking dog charging directly at them would instinctively attempt to evade or avoid the dog and could fall or be injured in doing so. See *Jupin*, 447 Mass. at 147–48 (foreseeability of harm where defendant allowed dangerous instrumentality to be misused).

*Bennett*, 408 Mass. at 359.proposition: Defendant’s violation of the posted leash rules, as well as applicable dog-control statutes and/or ordinances, constitutes evidence of negligence. See *Bennett*, 408 Mass. at 359; *Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp.*, 267 Mass. 501, 516 (1929) (violation of statute or ordinance as evidence of negligence).
*Bennett*, 408 Mass. at 359.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
*Bennett*, 408 Mass. at 359.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the evidentiary effect of violating safety-related statutes and ordinances. It reiterates the Massachusetts rule that such a violation is not negligence per se but is “some evidence” of negligence as to the harms the statute was meant to prevent. That is exactly the limited proposition for which Bennett is cited here: that violation of applicable control rules (there, liquor-control; here, leash/dog-control) constitutes evidence of negligence, not automatic liability.
*Bennett*, 408 Mass. at 359.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se… Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant’s negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

*Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp.*,.proposition: Defendant’s violation of the posted leash rules, as well as applicable dog-control statutes and/or ordinances, constitutes evidence of negligence. See *Bennett*, 408 Mass. at 359; *Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp.*, 267 Mass. 501, 516 (1929) (violation of statute or ordinance as evidence of negligence).
*Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the Massachusetts rule that violation of a statute, ordinance, or regulation is evidence of negligence as to the harms the enactment was intended to prevent. Although the facts involve fire-prevention regulations about motion picture film rather than dog-control rules, the legal principle is articulated in general terms and thus directly supports citing Guinan for the evidentiary effect of a statutory or regulatory violation in a negligence case.
*Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp.*,.relevant_excerpt: “The regulations have the force and effect of law. A violation of a statute, ordinance or regulation, although not conclusive, is evidence of negligence on the part of a violator as to all consequences that the statute, ordinance or regulation was intended to prevent. Wright v. Malden & Melrose Railroad, 4 Allen, 283, 290. Lane v. Atlantic Works, 111 Mass. 136, 140. … Gordon v. Bedard, 265 Mass. 408, 411.”

*Doull v. Foster*, 487 Mass. 1, 8\u20131.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a substantial contributing factor in causing Plaintiff’s fall and resulting injuries. See *Doull v. Foster*, 487 Mass. 1, 8–11 (2021) (substantial factor and factual cause in negligence actions).

*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.proposition: The injuries suffered by Plaintiff were within the scope of the foreseeable risk created by Defendant’s conduct, and there were no superseding or intervening causes that would relieve Defendant of liability. See *Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 Mass. 37, 45–46 (2009).
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.support_reasoning: The cited pages squarely hold the opposite of the claimed proposition. The court concludes that, even assuming negligence, Leavitt’s injuries were *outside* the scope of the foreseeable risk created by the hospital’s conduct and therefore not within the hospital’s scope of liability. The court emphasizes that the collision involving the police cruiser and an unrelated vehicle was not the same general type of danger that made the alleged release of a medicated patient negligent, and thus causation (proximate cause/scope of liability) was lacking.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.relevant_excerpt: “Leavitt’s injury was not ‘caused’ by the hospital because it falls outside the scope of foreseeable risk arising from any negligent conduct that would make the hospital’s alleged misconduct tortious. … We reach the same conclusion here: the harm that befell Leavitt — an injury from a collision not involving the patient — arose not from the ‘same general type of danger’ (harm to the patient or to those injured by the patient as a result of being released while medicated) that the hospital allegedly should have taken reasonable steps to avoid, but from ‘some other danger.’”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff has incurred, and will continue to incur, reasonable and necessary medical expenses related to diagnosis, treatment, and rehabilitation of her injuries in an amount presently estimated at approximately Four Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($4,500.00), and potentially more, subject to proof at trial. See G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest in tort actions).

*Conway v. Electro Switch Corp.*, 402 Ma.proposition: Plaintiff has endured physical pain and suffering, emotional distress, mental anguish, and loss of enjoyment of life, including but not limited to the inability to work for a period of time, limitations on daily activities, and the loss of the opportunity to perform in a piano recital she had practiced for extensively. See *Conway v. Electro Switch Corp.*, 402 Mass. 385, 390–91 (1988) (damages for pain and suffering); *Rodrigues v. State*, 52 Haw. 156, 472 P.2d 509 (1970) (recognizing emotional distress damages), cited favorably in *Payton v. Abbott Labs.*, 386 Mass. 540, 545–47 (1982).
*Conway v. Electro Switch Corp.*, 402 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion in Conway concerns the availability of front pay and prejudgment interest under Mass. Gen. Laws c. 151B. It discusses compensatory damages in terms of lost pay, future earnings, and benefits, not damages for physical pain and suffering, emotional distress, mental anguish, or loss of enjoyment of life, nor any specific limitations on activities such as inability to work or missing a piano recital. It is therefore not authority for the detailed personal injury–style damages described in the proposition, and citing it for “damages for pain and suffering” is inaccurate in this context.
*Conway v. Electro Switch Corp.*, 402 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In the context of employment discrimination which is found to be in violation of G. L. c. 151B, compensatory damages are those damages which ‘make[ ] the aggrieved party whole,’ Bournewood Hosp., Inc. v. MCAD, 371 Mass. 303, 315 (1976), including those which are ‘the natural and probable consequences,’ id. at 316, of the illegal conduct. We see nothing in the statute to suggest that an award of damages for loss of pay must be limited to the period preceding the date of judgment.”

*Rodrigues v. State*, 52 Haw. 156, 472 P.proposition: Plaintiff has endured physical pain and suffering, emotional distress, mental anguish, and loss of enjoyment of life, including but not limited to the inability to work for a period of time, limitations on daily activities, and the loss of the opportunity to perform in a piano recital she had practiced for extensively. See *Conway v. Electro Switch Corp.*, 402 Mass. 385, 390–91 (1988) (damages for pain and suffering); *Rodrigues v. State*, 52 Haw. 156, 472 P.2d 509 (1970) (recognizing emotional distress damages), cited favorably in *Payton v. Abbott Labs.*, 386 Mass. 540, 545–47 (1982).
*Rodrigues v. State*, 52 Haw. 156, 472 P.support_reasoning: Rodrigues squarely holds that Hawaii law recognizes an independent cause of action and damages for negligent infliction of serious emotional distress, including in a case involving damage to a home rather than personal injury. The court affirms, in principle, the recoverability of “mental anguish and suffering” as a compensable item and articulates the standard for negligent infliction of emotional distress, even though it remands for application of that standard to the facts. Thus the case properly supports the general proposition that emotional distress damages are recoverable.
*Rodrigues v. State*, 52 Haw. 156, 472 P.relevant_excerpt: “We recognize that the interest in freedom from negligent infliction of serious mental distress is entitled to independent legal protection. We hold, therefore, that there is a duty to refrain from the negligent infliction of serious mental distress… We turn then to a consideration of the policies underlying the present scheme of protection… We hold that serious mental distress may be found where a reasonable man, normally constituted, would be unable to adequately cope with the mental stress engendered by the circumstances of the case.”

*Payton v. Abbott Labs.*, 386 Mass. 540,.proposition: Plaintiff has endured physical pain and suffering, emotional distress, mental anguish, and loss of enjoyment of life, including but not limited to the inability to work for a period of time, limitations on daily activities, and the loss of the opportunity to perform in a piano recital she had practiced for extensively. See *Conway v. Electro Switch Corp.*, 402 Mass. 385, 390–91 (1988) (damages for pain and suffering); *Rodrigues v. State*, 52 Haw. 156, 472 P.2d 509 (1970) (recognizing emotional distress damages), cited favorably in *Payton v. Abbott Labs.*, 386 Mass. 540, 545–47 (1982).
*Payton v. Abbott Labs.*, 386 Mass. 540,.support_reasoning: Payton is about whether Massachusetts recognizes a cause of action for negligent infliction of emotional distress without physical harm, and it expressly denies such a claim in the context of fear of future disease from DES exposure. It does not discuss, define, or award categories of damages such as pain and suffering, emotional distress, loss of enjoyment of life, inability to work, or lost opportunities like a piano recital. Rodrigues is mentioned only as part of a survey of other jurisdictions on negligent emotional distress, not as adopted authority on the scope of compensable damages, so Payton does not support the detailed damages proposition asserted.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs.*, 386 Mass. 540,.relevant_excerpt: "We therefore conclude, on the basis of the proceeding analysis, that in order for any of these plaintiffs to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress, she must allege and prove she suffered physical harm as a result of the conduct which caused the emotional distress... In summary, we should that a plaintiff in order to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress must prove the following: (1) negligence; (2) emotional distress; (3) causations; (4) physical harm manifested by objective symptomatology; and (5) that a reasonable person would have suffered emotional distress under the circumstances of the case."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 60B, 85, 85J.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered all of the above damages in an amount to be determined by the trier of fact, but within the jurisdictional limits of this Court. See G.L. c. 231, §§ 60B, 85, 85J.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: WHEREFORE, Plaintiff Emily Johnson respectfully prays that this Honorable Court enter judgment in her favor and against Defendant Michael Thompson, and award the following relief: ... D. Costs of this action, including allowable filing fees and other taxable costs pursuant to G.L. c. 261;
